citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
The facility's USDA Animal Welfare Act required records including the written Program of Veterinary Care, the
Contingency Plan and a record of animals on hand (acquisition/disposition records) were not available for review during
the inspection. A fire occurred at the barn office about two years ago and records were destroyed. The facility
representative stated that the main office and the vet may have copies of some of the records. Access to the required
records is necessary to ensure compliance with the regulations. The facility shall ensure that the records required to be
kept by the Act and the regulations are available for USDA APHIS officials to examine. Correct by 4/30/23.

One older whitetail deer is currently being housed in the animal habitat also housing sheep, goats and a llama.
Approximately eight weeks ago there was an issue with dogs that were abandoned behind the park. The deer received a
severe injury to the flank area with torn skin and muscle when at least one of the dogs was able to enter the habitat and
attack the deer overnight while the park was closed. The deer underwent surgery and the wound has closed and healed.
An animal's enclosure must be constructed so that it is structurally sound and protects the animals from injury. The facility
has since had the stray dogs removed by Animal Control and has hired nighttime security to help keep out unwanted
animals and people. No further issues with stray dogs have occurred. Corrected at this time.

The enclosures currently housing exotic/wild species of animals (arctic fox, raccoon, coatimundi) are enclosed by a
perimeter fence that is 4 ft in height instead of the required 6 ft in height. There is no other perimeter fence around the
entire animal area or park. A perimeter fence of at least 6 ft in height is necessary to keep out unwanted animals and
unauthorized persons and to act as a secondary containment for the animals inside the enclosure. The facility shall
ensure that all housing facilities are enclosed by a perimeter fence at least 6 ft in height and 3 ft away from the primary
animal enclosures. Correct by 7/20/23.

The feeding trough in the animal habitat enclosure housing the llama, sheep, goats, and deer contained rotting fruit and
vegetables left over from being fed to the animals 24 hours ago. The produce was discolored, liquifying and smelled.
Many flies were present. The facility representative stated that the produce not eaten during the morning feeding is
usually removed around lunchtime but that yesterday's produce was not removed because of other ongoing activities.
Rotting contaminated food may cause digestive issues, odors and attract pests. The facility shall ensure that food is
wholesome, palatable and free from contamination. Correct by 5pm today 4/20/23.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.126(a)(2) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
The facility's USDA Animal Welfare Act required records including the written Program of Veterinary Care, the 
Contingency Plan and a record of animals on hand (acquisition/disposition records) were not available for review during 
the inspection. A fire occurred at the barn office about two years ago and records were destroyed. The facility 
representative stated that the main office and the vet may have copies of some of the records. Access to the required 
records is necessary to ensure compliance with the regulations. The facility shall ensure that the records required to be 
kept by the Act and the regulations are available for USDA APHIS officials to examine. Correct by 4/30/23. 
3.125(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
One older whitetail deer is currently being housed in the animal habitat also housing sheep, goats and a llama. 
Approximately eight weeks ago there was an issue with dogs that were abandoned behind the park. The deer received a 
severe injury to the flank area with torn skin and muscle when at least one of the dogs was able to enter the habitat and 
attack the deer overnight while the park was closed. The deer underwent surgery and the wound has closed and healed. 
An animal's enclosure must be constructed so that it is structurally sound and protects the animals from injury. The facility

has since had the stray dogs removed by Animal Control and has hired nighttime security to help keep out unwanted 
animals and people. No further issues with stray dogs have occurred. Corrected at this time. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The enclosures currently housing exotic/wild species of animals (arctic fox, raccoon, coatimundi) are enclosed by a 
perimeter fence that is 4 ft in height instead of the required 6 ft in height. There is no other perimeter fence around the 
entire animal area or park. A perimeter fence of at least 6 ft in height is necessary to keep out unwanted animals and 
unauthorized persons and to act as a secondary containment for the animals inside the enclosure. The facility shall 
ensure that all housing facilities are enclosed by a perimeter fence at least 6 ft in height and 3 ft away from the primary 
animal enclosures. Correct by 7/20/23. 
3.129(a) 
   
Feeding. 
The feeding trough in the animal habitat enclosure housing the llama, sheep, goats, and deer  contained rotting fruit and 
vegetables left over from being fed to the animals 24 hours ago. The produce was discolored, liquifying and smelled. 
Many flies were present. The facility representative stated that the produce not eaten during the morning feeding is 
usually removed around lunchtime but that yesterday's produce was not removed because of other ongoing activities. 
Rotting contaminated food may cause digestive issues, odors and attract pests. The facility shall ensure that food is 
wholesome, palatable and free from contamination. Correct by 5pm today 4/20/23. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
